solution: Da $\sqrt{3} \cos \theta - \sin \theta = \frac{1}{3},$ si ha \[\sin \theta = \sqrt{3} \cos \theta - \frac{1}{3}.\]Sostituendo in $\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1,$ si ottiene \[3 \cos^2 \theta - \frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{3} \cos \theta + \frac{1}{9} + \cos^2 \theta = 1.\]Questo si semplifica in $18 \cos^2 \theta - 3 \sqrt{3} \cos \theta - 4 = 0.$ Applicando la formula quadratica, \[\cos \theta = \frac{\sqrt{3} \pm \sqrt{35}}{12}.\]Poiché $0 < \theta < \frac{\pi}{2},$ $\cos \theta$ è positiva, quindi $\cos \theta = \frac{\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{35}}{12}.$ Quindi, \begin{align*} \sqrt{3} \sin \theta + \cos \theta &= \sqrt{3} \left( \sqrt{3} \cos \theta - \frac{1}{3} \right) + \cos \theta \\ &= 3 \cos \theta - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} + \cos \theta \\ &= 4 \cos \theta - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{35}}{3} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{35}}{3}}. \end{align*}
